captions.text:
Who's the greatest physicist in history?DeGrasse
Tyson:    Isaac Newton.  I mean, just

look... You read his writings.  Hair stands
up... I don't have hair there but if I did,

it would stand up on the back of my neck. 
You read his writings, the man was connected

to the universe in ways that I never seen
another human being connected.  It's kind

of spooky actually.  He discovers the laws
of optics, figured out that white light is

composed of colors.  That's kind of freaky
right there.  You take your colors of the

rainbow, put them back together, you have
white light again.  That freaked out the

artist of the day.  How does that work? 
Red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet gives

you white.  The laws of optics.  He discovers
the laws of motion and the universal law of

gravitation.  Then, a friend of his says,
"Well, why do these orbits of the planets...

Why are they in a shape of an ellipse, sort
of flattened circle?  Why aren't... some

other shape?"  He said, you know, "I can't...
I don't know.  I'll get back to you."  So

he goes... goes home, comes back couple of
months later, "Here's why.  They're actually

conic sections, sections of a cone that you
cut."  And... And he said, "Well, how did

find this out?  How did you determine this?" 
"Well, I had to invent integral and differential

calculus to determine this."  Then, he turned
26.  Then, he turned 26.  We got people

slogging through calculus in college just
to learn what it is that Isaac Newtown invented

on a dare, practically.  So that's my man,
Isaac Newton.

Question: Who's the greatest physicist in
history?DeGrasse Tyson:    Isaac Newton.

I mean, just look... You read his writings. 
Hair stands up... I don't have hair there

but if I did, it would stand up on the back
of my neck.  You read his writings, the man

was connected to the universe in ways that
I never seen another human being connected.

It's kind of spooky actually.  He discovers
the laws of optics, figured out that white

light is composed of colors.  That's kind
of freaky right there.  You take your colors

of the rainbow, put them back together, you
have white light again.  That freaked out

the artist of the day.  How does that work? 
Red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet gives

you white.  The laws of optics.  He discovers
the laws of motion and the universal law of

gravitation.  Then, a friend of his says,
"Well, why do these orbits of the planets...

Why are they in a shape of an ellipse, sort
of flattened circle?  Why aren't... some

other shape?"  He said, you know, "I can't...
I don't know.  I'll get back to you."  So

he goes... goes home, comes back couple of
months later, "Here's why.  They're actually

conic sections, sections of a cone that you
cut."  And... And he said, "Well, how did

find this out?  How did you determine this?" 
"Well, I had to invent integral and differential

calculus to determine this."  Then, he turned
26.  Then, he turned 26.  We got people

slogging through calculus in college just
to learn what it is that Isaac Newtown invented

on a dare, practically.  So that's my man,
Isaac Newton.

title: Neil deGrasse Tyson: My Man, Sir Isaac Newton

comments.author: Dejan Janković

comments.text:
+Dejan Janković So tell me, specifically what did Tesla do that gives him 
the title "real hero"? Did he completely change the course of mathematics 
and discover superfluous optical properties like Isaac Newton? Did he find 
the complex nature of quantum physics like Bohr, Heisenberg, Einstein, 
Rutherford, Planck, Michelson, and Young? Did he advance the field of 
electromagnetism like Maxwell? 
Don't get me wrong, Tesla was certainly a genius in electrical engineering 
(X-rays in particular) and definitely deserves the credit that he is 
receiving these days. But just because you're Serbian doesn't mean that 
Tesla should be considered a "real hero". You simple-minded nationalist 
need to get your head out of your ass and discover that there are many more 
brilliant physicists than just Tesla. Who, by the way, received his 
American citizenship later in his life. Still want to bash on capitalists?

comments.text:
+CHistrue Socialism has absolutely nothing to do with classical 
liberalism. Of course you haven't seen the state wither away, that can only 
happen on international/continental socialism. The state would wither away, 
Vladimir Lenin makes this quite clear in "State & Revolution". the State 
only exists for one class to oppress another, and when class is abolished, 
the state ceases to exist. 

I don't think you quite understand what fascism is, Stalinist Russia 
certainly wasn't it. Plus Stalin opposed his cult of personality. I'm not 
'interested in communism', I am a communist. I made this account and this 
comment before I was a communist.
comments.author: DukeOfWellington

comments.text:
+DukeOfWellington Perhaps.  I consider Marx's scientific analysis of class 
to be superior to anything I have read.  It actually built itself on 
classical liberalism in many respects.  Marx even praised the American 
Jacksonians as paving the way for a victory of working people that would 
not require revolution.  (A bit naively when you consider the racial record 
of the Jacksonians, but I digress.)  

Where Marx loses me is when he becomes a kind of Atheist Creationist, 
believing in absurdities like the State that Withers Away.  I am skeptical 
of that idea since I have never seen a State, even a genuine Worker's 
State, ever wither away.  At least left anarchists are realists in that 
they understand that the abolition of the state and the abolition of 
capitalism would have to occur together in one swoop, not one after the 
other.  But, as I said before, I respect Marx as a thinker superior to 
other Philosophical Materialists who then as now frame(d) their views on 
the unstated premises of Victorian Capitalism (Dawkins, Galton, Bertrand 
Russell, et al)

Stalin became a Fascist in all but name so the whole "communism" ideal 
changed.  Besides, if you are so interested in communism you should know 
that Marx was the biggest enemy of the whole "Sir" idea and title of 
nobility. So why the whole "Sir" Isaac Newton business?
comments.author: CHistrue

the reason for a lot of the wars, death and religious conflict of late 
times, and older times too. Since the 90's you've been at war with the 
Islamics, when shall you fix these problems, or with regards to the 
Japanese that you bombed with wrongfully created atomic bombs from 
Einstein; children in Japan are still being born today with radiation 
sickness.

All your leader ever states is "One can not bomb us, but if one does bomb 
us it's perfectly fine for us to bomb them." Fighting fire with fire is all 
we see from USA. It have some of the worst educational, food, work and 
court systems in the world, indeed the worst of the 1st world countries 
that much is clear. We all have bad history, the difference is, USA seems 
to be built purely on the basis of war, military and money.
